snp1.2:1.1.eng: “I’ve boiled my rice and drawn my milk,”
snp1.2:1.1.comm: This verse evidently refers to his completion of a daily household (Sanskrit gṛhya) rite involving offering of cooked food (Sanskrit pākayajña), guaranteeing abundant cattle and offspring (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.8.1.9).

snp1.2:1.2.comm: Dhaniya means “wealthy man”, and gopa, while it literally means “cowherd”, here refers to someone who owns and manages a substantial cattle estate, i.e. a “rancher”.

snp1.2:1.3.eng: “I stay with my family along the bank of the Mahī.

snp1.2:1.4.eng: My hut is roofed, my sacred fire kindled:
snp1.2:1.4.comm: “My fire kindled” (āhito gini, cf. Sanskrit āhitāgni) refers to one who has set up his fire altar.

snp1.2:1.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”
snp1.2:1.5.comm: Through his offering he invokes the god of thunder and rain (Indra or Pajjuna, Sanskrit Parjanya) to bless the land with life-giving waters (per eg. Atharva Veda 4.15).

snp1.2:2.1.eng: “I boil not with anger <j>and have drawn out hard-heartedness,”
snp1.2:2.1.comm: The verse first puns pakkodano (“boiled rice”) with akkodhano (“without anger”), then khīra (“milk”) with khila (“hard-heartedness”).

snp1.2:2.3.eng: “I stay for one night along the bank of the Mahī.

snp1.2:2.4.eng: My hut is wide open, my fire is quenched:
snp1.2:2.4.comm: The Buddha directly counters the kindled Vedic fire with Nibbana as the quenching of the flame.

snp1.2:2.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:3.3.eng: “cows graze on the lush meadow grass.

snp1.2:3.4.eng: They get by even when the rain comes:

snp1.2:3.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:4.1.eng: “I bound a raft and made it well,”

snp1.2:4.2.comm: Norman points out that this verse is not a proper response to the previous and suggests that a verse has been lost. I agree, but I disagree there is a contradiction in the sense. Rather, the verse tells a story over time. I translate to bring out the meaning.

snp1.2:4.3.eng: “and with it I crossed over, went to the far shore, <j>and dispelled the flood.

snp1.2:4.4.eng: Now I have no need for a raft:

snp1.2:4.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:5.4.eng: I hear nothing bad about her:

snp1.2:5.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:6.4.eng: Nothing bad is found in me:

snp1.2:6.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:7.3.comm: I’m not convinced by the commentary’s “not separated”. It doesn’t seem to occur in this meaning elsewhere, and lacks a connection with the opening line. Surely the whole verse must be about the children, which requires that there be a comparison made with the first line. The point is, I think, that the children follow the father and have become self-sufficient. This also echoes better with the Buddha’s response.

snp1.2:7.4.eng: I hear nothing bad about them:

snp1.2:7.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:8.3.eng: “with what I have earned I wander the world.

snp1.2:8.4.eng: I have no need for wages:

snp1.2:8.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:9.4.eng: I’ve also got a bull, captain of the herd here:

snp1.2:9.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:10.3.eng: “no cows in calf or breeding cows.

snp1.2:10.4.eng: I haven’t got a bull, captain of the herd here:

snp1.2:10.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:11.3.eng: “The grass halters are new and well-woven,

snp1.2:11.4.eng: not even the sucklings can break them:

snp1.2:11.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:12.1.eng: “Like a bull I broke the bonds,”

snp1.2:12.3.eng: “like an elephant I snapped the vine.

snp1.2:12.4.eng: I will never lie in a womb again:

snp1.2:12.5.eng: so rain forth, heavens, if you wish.”

snp1.2:13.1.eng: Right then a vast cloud rained forth,
snp1.2:13.1.comm: For all Dhaniya’s offerings, his capricious god deals out life-threatening flood instead of life-giving waters. It is not just that his supposed security turns out to be insecure, but that his religious devotions were misplaced, setting the stage for his conversion.

snp1.2:14.1.eng: “It is no small gain for us

snp1.2:14.2.eng: that we have seen the Buddha.

snp1.2:14.3.eng: We come to you for refuge, Clear-eyed One.

snp1.2:14.4.eng: O great sage, please be our Teacher.

snp1.2:15.2.eng: shall lead the spiritual life under the Holy One.
snp1.2:15.2.comm: Norman and Bodhi apparently read the middle form carāmase as imperative, but I take it as the present indicative in the sense of definite future.

snp1.2:15.4.eng: we shall make an end of suffering.”

snp1.2:16.4.eng: For attachments are a man’s delight;

snp1.2:16.5.pli: Na hi so nandati yo nirūpadhi”.

snp1.2:17.4.eng: For attachments are a man’s sorrow;

snp1.2:17.5.pli: Na hi so socati yo nirūpadhī”ti.
snp1.2:17.5.eng: without attachments there are no sorrows.”

snp1.3:1.1.eng: When you’ve laid down arms toward all creatures,

snp1.3:1.2.eng: not harming even a single one,

snp1.3:1.3.eng: don’t wish for a child, let alone a companion:

snp1.3:1.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:2.1.eng: Those with close relationships have affection,

snp1.3:2.3.eng: Seeing this danger born of affection,

snp1.3:2.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:3.1.eng: When feelings for friends and loved ones

snp1.3:3.2.eng: are tied up in selfish love, you miss out on the goal.

snp1.3:3.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:4.1.eng: As a spreading bamboo gets entangled,

snp1.3:4.2.eng: so does concern for partners and children.

snp1.3:4.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:5.1.eng: As a wild deer loose in the forest

snp1.3:5.3.eng: a smart person looking for freedom would

snp1.3:5.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:6.1.eng: When among friends, whether staying in place

snp1.3:6.2.eng: or going on a journey, you’re always on call.

snp1.3:6.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:7.1.eng: Among friends you have fun and games,

snp1.3:7.2.eng: and for children you are full of fondness.

snp1.3:7.3.eng: Though loathe to depart from those you hold dear,

snp1.3:7.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:8.1.eng: At ease in any quarter, unresisting,

snp1.3:8.2.eng: content with whatever comes your way;

snp1.3:8.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:9.1.eng: Even some renunciates are hard to please,

snp1.3:9.2.eng: as are some layfolk dwelling at home.

snp1.3:9.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:10.1.eng: Having shed the marks of the home life,

snp1.3:10.2.eng: like the fallen leaves of the Shady Orchid Tree;

snp1.3:10.3.eng: having cut the bonds of the home life, a hero would

snp1.3:10.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:11.1.eng: If you find an alert companion,

snp1.3:11.2.eng: an attentive friend to live happily together,

snp1.3:11.4.eng: wander with them, joyful and mindful.

snp1.3:12.1.eng: If you find no alert companion,

snp1.3:12.2.eng: an attentive friend to live happily together,

snp1.3:12.3.eng: then, like a king who flees his conquered realm,

snp1.3:12.4.eng: wander alone like a tusker in the wilds.

snp1.3:13.1.eng: Clearly we praise the blessing of a friend,

snp1.3:13.2.eng: it’s good to be with friends your equal or better.

snp1.3:13.3.eng: but failing to find them, eating blamelessly,

snp1.3:13.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:14.1.eng: Though made of shining gold, <j>well-finished by a smith,

snp1.3:14.2.eng: when two bracelets share the same arm

snp1.3:14.3.eng: they clash up against each other. Seeing this,

snp1.3:14.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:15.1.eng: Thinking, “So too, if I had a partner,

snp1.3:15.2.comm: The exact nuance of this line is hard to pin down. Later Pali texts equate abhilāpa with “naming”, but it doesn’t seem to occur in any early texts with this sense. However lapanā is used in the sense of “flattery” in eg. MN 117:29.2.

snp1.3:15.3.eng: Seeing this peril in the future,

snp1.3:15.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:16.1.eng: Sensual pleasures are diverse, sweet, delightful,

snp1.3:16.2.eng: appearing in disguise they disturb the mind.

snp1.3:16.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:17.1.eng: This is a calamity, a boil, a disaster,

snp1.3:17.2.eng: an illness, a dart, and a danger for me.

snp1.3:17.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:18.1.eng: Heat and cold, hunger and thirst,

snp1.3:18.2.eng: wind and sun, flies and snakes:

snp1.3:18.3.eng: having put up with all these things,

snp1.3:18.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:19.1.eng: As a full-grown elephant, lotus-fond, magnificent,

snp1.3:19.2.comm: Padumī is a word for “elephant”, after the lotus-like spots or mottles on an elephant’s body, or else due to their fondness for lotuses (padmaprasaktyā, Mātaṅgalīla); elephants are often seen bathing and eating in lotus ponds.

snp1.3:19.3.eng: stays as it pleases in the forest,

snp1.3:19.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:20.1.eng: It’s impossible for one who delights in company

snp1.3:20.3.eng: Heeding the speech of the Kinsman of the Sun,

snp1.3:20.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:21.1.eng: Thinking, “I have left twisted views behind,

snp1.3:21.2.eng: reached the sure way, and gained the path;

snp1.3:21.3.eng: I’ve given rise to knowledge, <j>and need no-one to guide me”,

snp1.3:21.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:22.1.eng: No greed, no guile, no thirst, no slur,

snp1.3:22.2.eng: dross and delusion is smelted off;
snp1.3:22.2.comm: The reference is to the smelting of gold, AN 3.101:1.9.

snp1.3:22.3.eng: free of hoping for anything in the world,

snp1.3:22.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:23.2.eng: blind to the good, habitually immoral.

snp1.3:23.3.eng: Don’t befriend the heedless and the hankering, but

snp1.3:23.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:24.1.eng: Spend time with the learned <j>who have memorized the teachings,

snp1.3:24.3.eng: When you understand the meanings <j>and have dispelled doubt,

snp1.3:24.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:25.1.eng: When you realize that worldly fun and games

snp1.3:25.2.eng: and pleasure are inadequate, <j>unconcerned with them,

snp1.3:25.3.eng: as one unadorned, a speaker of truth,

snp1.3:25.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:26.3.eng: having given up sensual pleasures to this extent,

snp1.3:26.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:27.1.eng: “This is a chain. Here there’s hardly any happiness,

snp1.3:27.2.eng: little gratification, and it’s full of drawbacks.

snp1.3:27.3.eng: It’s a hook.” Knowing this, a thoughtful person would

snp1.3:27.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:28.2.eng: like a fish that tears the net and swims free,

snp1.3:28.3.eng: or a fire not returning to ground it has burned,

snp1.3:28.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:29.3.eng: not festering or burning with desire,

snp1.3:29.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:30.1.eng: Having shed the marks of the home life,

snp1.3:30.2.eng: like the fallen leaves of the Shady Orchid Tree,

snp1.3:30.3.eng: and gone forth in the ocher robe,

snp1.3:30.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:31.1.eng: Not wanton, nor rousing greed for tastes,

snp1.3:31.2.eng: providing for no other, <j>wandering indiscriminately for alms,

snp1.3:31.3.eng: not attached to this family or that,

snp1.3:31.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:32.1.eng: When you’ve given up five mental obstacles,

snp1.3:32.3.eng: and cut off affection and hate, being independent,

snp1.3:32.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:33.1.eng: When you’ve put pleasure and pain behind you,

snp1.3:33.3.eng: and gained equanimity serene and pure,

snp1.3:33.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:34.1.eng: With energy roused to reach the ultimate goal,

snp1.3:34.2.eng: not sluggish in mind or lazy,

snp1.3:34.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:35.2.eng: always living in line with the teaching,

snp1.3:35.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:36.1.eng: One whose aim is the ending of craving—

snp1.3:36.3.eng: who has appraised the teaching and is destined for awakening, should

snp1.3:36.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:37.1.eng: Like a lion not startled by sounds,

snp1.3:37.2.eng: like wind not caught in a net,

snp1.3:37.3.eng: like water not sticking to a lotus,

snp1.3:37.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:38.1.eng: Like the fierce-fanged lion, king of beasts,

snp1.3:38.2.eng: who wanders as conqueror and victor,

snp1.3:38.3.eng: you should frequent remote lodgings, and

snp1.3:38.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:39.3.eng: Not upset by anything in the world,

snp1.3:39.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:40.1.eng: Having given up greed, hate, and delusion,

snp1.3:40.3.eng: unafraid at the end of life,

snp1.3:40.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.

snp1.3:41.1.eng: They befriend you and serve you for their own sake;

snp1.3:41.2.eng: these days it’s hard to find friends <j>lacking ulterior motive.

snp1.3:41.4.eng: live alone like a horned rhino.
